fields.value: CAPS Debates and Debate Ratings (CAPS-DEBATE CAPS-DEBATE1 CAPS_DEBATE2 and CAPS-DEBRATE modules)

dsDescriptionValue.value:
A preliminary unit, LINPRE, measures the panel's initial attitudes toward six potential debate topics. The topic which yielded the most divergent distribution of attitudes was used as the topic for both debates.

DEBATE1 provided an introduction to the debate and explained the purpose of the study (to assess the characteristics of debating in an electronic medium). It set the rules for exposition and asked the students several questions about how they felt, including how anxious they wer e. Rs were assigned their side of the debate topic and entered their cases. Follow-up questions assessed their anxiety and how they felt while entering their arguments.

In DEBATE2, the Rs argued the opposite side of the issue. The same question modules as in DEBATE1 were presented before and after the debate.

In DEBRATE Rs are asked to rate two debates from the DEBATE1 DEBATE2 units. Rs were told that they were competing with one other department and that the department of the two which won the most debates (based on the ratings) would receive a $100 bonus in its department account. The debates rated were those of a person who is neither a member o f Rs own team nor the team with which they are in competition, so their ratings could not affect their own department's chances of winning. Rs rated the debates on persuasiveness, how well-developed they are, and how much the argument influenced their own opinion on the issue. They also indicated how strongly they agree or disagree with the debate statement: 'The NC drinking age should be lowered to 18.'

Two BASIC programs, (DEBATER and DEBSCORE) are used to calculate scores and determine the winning departments in each debate. In CAPS88, the winning department of each pair on each of the two debates was awarded a $100 bonus in the department account. Winning departments were announced in the final CAPS session.

Within (W) and between (B) subjects independent variables in this unit were (W) debate position (pro/con), (W) number of team members (one/four), (B) number of opposition me mbers (one/four) and (B) number of raters (2/4/16). Potential covariates were order of debate position (pro-con, con-pro), order of number of t eam members (one-four, four-one), familiarity with topic (0-100), own position on topic (0-100), perceived others position on topic (0-100), self rating of how convincing arguments will be and confidence before debate (0-100). The dependent variables were level of anxiety before and after debate (0-100), change of position on issue (0-100), difficulty (0-100), self rating of how convincing arguments were (0-100), and others' ratings of how convincing arguments were (0-100).

No standard scoring.
